title: When your SMSF can buy property from (or rent to) a family member
text:
Acquiring a property can extend to just getting it without money changing hands – for example, sometimes members transfer things they already own into their SMSF as a “contribution” rather than using cash. Again, if the “thing” was a property, it would need to be “business real property” for this to be allowed.

The second situation is if – once the fund owns it – the trustee wishes to rent it to a related party. Again, SMSF trustees are quite entitled to own any kind of property and rent it out to someone else (in fact, there’s not much point owning it if they don’t). But if the person, company or trust that they are renting it to is a related party, they can only do that if it’s business real property.

To re-cap, it’s fine for an SMSF to own pretty much any property. Whether or not it’s business real property only matters if the trustees want to buy it (or receive it without money changing hands) from a related party or rent it to a related party.

If they plan to buy it from strangers and rent it to strangers, it doesn’t matter whether it’s a house, a shop or a bit of both. If they plan to buy it from a family member and then rent it to strangers, they only care whether it’s business real property at the time it’s being bought – once it’s in the fund it doesn’t matter any more.

So on those occasions when it really does matter whether the property is business or residential, what are the important things to look out for?

If there is anything at all going on at the property other than a business, don’t assume it meets the definition of business real property.

Business real property in a superannuation sense means that the property is actively being used in a business or normally would be (even it's between tenants). So, for example, just being zoned for commercial purposes isn’t enough. And generally vacant land doesn’t make the grade either because it’s not actually being used for anything. Of course there are exceptions – if the property in question is a farm, it’s fine to have some empty paddocks. But a property that is simply an empty block in an industrial estate that’s not being used for anything would be a problem.

It must also be “wholly and exclusively” used in the business – a shop that has a residence upstairs normally fails here. There are exceptions where there’s only a small part of the property that’s not used by the business or where it’s a farm that has a family home on it. But in short, if there is anything at all going on at the property other than a business, don’t assume it meets the definition of business real property.

Overall, business real property is a key piece of superannuation language and has a very specific meaning. When it’s important, it’s really important. But sometimes it doesn’t matter whether a property is business real property or not. It always pays to check.

Meg Heffron is MD at SMSF specialist firm Heffron.
description: It's got to be classified as 'business real property'. But just being zoned for commercial purposes isn’t enough. And vacant land doesn’t make the grade either.
